citeinfo.origin: US Army Corps of Engineers Long Term Resource Monitoring Program, a component of the Upper Mississippi River Restoration- Environmental Management Program and USGS's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center
citeinfo.title: UMRS LTRMP 2010/11 LCU Mapping -- Pool 4

pubinfo.pubplace: Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center; La Crosse, WI
pubinfo.publish: US Army Corps of Engineers Long Term Resource Monitoring Program, a component of the Upper Mississippi River Restoration- Environmental Management Program and USGS's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center

descript.abstract: Aerial photographs for Pools 1-13 Upper Mississippi River System and Pools, Alton-Marseilles, Illinois River were collected in color infrared (CIR) in August of 2010 at 8”/pixel and 16”/pixel respectively using a mapping-grade Applanix DSS 439 digital aerial camera. In August 2011, CIR aerial photographs for Pools 14-Open River South, Upper Mississippi River and Pools Dresden-Lockport, Illinois River were collected at 16”/pixel with the same camera. All CIR aerial photos were orthorectified, mosaicked, compressed, and served via the UMESC Internet site. The CIR aerial photos were interpreted and automated using a 31-class LTRMP vegetation classification. The 2010/11 LCU databases were prepared by or under the supervision of competent and trained professional staff using documented standard operated procedures and are subject to rigorous quality control (QC) assurances (NBS, 1995).
descript.purpose: Development of the 2010/11 Land Cover/Land Use (LCU) Geographic Information System (GIS) database will provide a third systemic dataset to compare the 1989 and the 2000 systemic coverages. Though a crosswalk was needed to compare 1989 and 2000 since different vegetation classification systems were used, the 2000 and 2010/11 LCU datasets will use the same classification and classifiers, making them directly comparable. Once completed, the 2010/11 dataset will be invaluable in assessing and evaluating long-term vegetation trends and habitat changes over the past 20 years, and in assessing the current state of floodplain vegetation.
descript.supplinf: The geographic extent of the UMRS is the Mississippi River floodplain from Cairo, IL to Minneapolis, MN and the Illinois River floodplain from its confluence with the Mississippi near Grafton, IL to Lake Michigan. National Vegetation Classification Standard v. 2 (12-1-2011) was used for supplemental vegetation information. Pools north of Lock & Dam 13, Upper Mississippi River were mapped with a minimum mapping unit (MMU) of 1-acre. Pools south of Lock & Dam 13, Upper Mississippi River and the Illinois River were mapped with a MMU of 1-hectare.

idinfo.accconst: Restriction Code: other restrictions; Other Constraints: Access constraints: Ability to see and use ESRI shapefiles
idinfo.datacred: US Army Corps of Engineers Long Term Resource Monitoring Program, a component of the Upper Mississippi River Restoration- Environmental Management Program and USGS's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center

idinfo.useconst: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty has been expressed or implied regarding the individual use of the data or aggregate use with other data, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.

attracc.attraccr: The attribute accuracy for this data set is tested on-screen if using the interpreted aerial images as a background data layer. The attributes are also checked against an all-inclusive list of possible attributes for the data set.

srcinfo.srccontr: Elevation data, where available, used to ortho correct imagery
Elevation data used to orthocorrect imagery

procstep.procdesc: Created stereo models of the 2010/11 Aerial Imagery
Heads up 3D digitizing on the 2010/11 Aerial Imagery stereo models in ArcGIS using Stereo Analyst
Attribute of polygons in ArcMap using USGS LTRMP developed classification system
Error checking and topology creation in ArcGIS
Attribute and linework quality control assurance steps

dataIdInfo.idPurp: Development of the 2010/11 Land Cover/Land Use (LCU) Geographic Information System (GIS) database will provide a third systemic dataset to compare the 1989 and the 2000 systemic coverages. Though a crosswalk was needed to compare 1989 and 2000 since different vegetation classification systems were used, the 2000 and 2010/11 LCU datasets will use the same classification and classifiers, making them directly comparable. Once completed, the 2010/11 dataset will be invaluable in assessing and evaluating long-term vegetation trends and habitat changes over the past 20 years, and in assessing the current state of floodplain vegetation.
dataIdInfo.idAbs: Aerial photographs for Pools 1-13 Upper Mississippi River System and Pools, Alton-Marseilles, Illinois River were collected in color infrared (CIR) in August of 2010 at 8”/pixel and 16”/pixel respectively using a mapping-grade Applanix DSS 439 digital aerial camera. In August 2011, CIR aerial photographs for Pools 14-Open River South, Upper Mississippi River and Pools Dresden-Lockport, Illinois River were collected at 16”/pixel with the same camera. All CIR aerial photos were orthorectified, mosaicked, compressed, and served via the UMESC Internet site. The CIR aerial photos were interpreted and automated using a 31-class LTRMP vegetation classification. The 2010/11 LCU databases were prepared by or under the supervision of competent and trained professional staff using documented standard operated procedures and are subject to rigorous quality control (QC) assurances (NBS, 1995).
dataIdInfo.idCredit: US Army Corps of Engineers Long Term Resource Monitoring Program, a component of the Upper Mississippi River Restoration- Environmental Management Program and USGS's Upper Midwest Environmental Sciences Center
dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
The geographic extent of the UMRS is the Mississippi River floodplain from Cairo, IL to Minneapolis, MN and the Illinois River floodplain from its confluence with the Mississippi near Grafton, IL to Lake Michigan.
National Vegetation Classification Standard Version 2 was used for this classification. The version used was current as of 12-1-2011.
Pools north of Lock & Dam 13, Upper Mississippi River were mapped with a minimum mapping unit (MMU) of 1-acre. Pools south of Lock & Dam 13, Upper Mississippi River and the Illinois River were mapped with a MMU of 1-hectare.
dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.5.0.6491
